lexUnit.name: lift.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to move or bring (something) upward from the ground or other support to a higher position

sentence.text: Marcus lying bloodied and broken , at this very moment being lifted into an ambulance , the red blanket being pulled up over his beautiful face .
The curds are lifted onto muslin-covered racks and cut through with a knife before they are left to drain .
Then she lifted the receiver while still holding out her other hand for the dog to lick .
My staff had to lift everything for me at work . "
Lift the knees towards the chest .
I tried to lift Joey into my arms but he wriggled onto the slack and ashes on the floor and started giggling .
She lifted the tea-cosy off the pot and pointed the spout meaningfully at him .
The one-legged beggar lifted his head from his bowl of vegetables and spiced meat and shook his head .
I lift another heap of pages out of the file and something falls out on my knees â€¦
Lift the plants from the heeling-in trench very carefully .
Like the woman who lifts the car off her child trapped beneath it .
The sluice gates are lifted by chains on old fashioned rollers .
This provides the strength for the chair to be lifted by its arms .
Each unit could be lifted by six men and fitted a standard three-ton lorry .
The cage was lifted up by the crane and stopped when we were 160 feet above the ground .
The fishermen were lifted out two at a time by a DHC Beaver floatplane and ` DRD was repaired .
A bookseller named James Gibb extended his Bible to more than sixty folio volumes , each so heavy that it could be lifted only with difficulty .
